awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Understanding Carrier Multiplication in Black Phosphorus for High-Gain MWIR Avalanche Photodiodes
awd_abstract_narration:
Black phosphorus is an emerging "two-dimensional" semiconductor material with many extraordinary optical and electronic properties. In particular, black phosphorus has strong optical absorption in the mid-infrared wavelength range, has high electrical current carrying capacity, and can be transferred onto a variety of substrates in layers only a few nanometers thick. For these reasons, black phosphorus could be a revolutionary platform for adaptable infrared imagers and optical communications systems. However, in order to achieve this promise, the process by which charge carriers multiply to create gain must be understood. This project seeks to understand one such gain mechanism, avalanche multiplication through impact ionization, which to date, as not been studied in black phosphorus. This basic physical mechanism will be studied by fabricating nanoscale device structures which will be tested using steady-state and time-dependent electrical measurements as well as optical techniques. These studies can provide fundamental understanding of impact ionization that will be important to realize new types of infrared imaging systems with higher sensitivity and tunability, as well as lower cost, compared to state-of-the-art solutions. The learning from this project will also be broadly applicable to a wide range of other devices using black phosphorus, including light emitters, logic and memory devices and even sensors. In this way, this work could help to realize a transformative technological platform for high-performance, low-cost flexible imagers and electronics. The program will also incorporate training for graduate and undergraduate students in nanoelectronics, and provides natural opportunities for hands-on activities for students at the primary and secondary educational level to illustrate nanoscience concepts.

The technical goals of this research program are to evaluate and understand the process of impact ionization in black phosphorus and to analyze the avalanche gain mechanism in photodiodes made using this material. These goals will be met by using high-precision electron-beam lithography to fabricate metal-semiconductor-metal device structures on exfoliated black phosphorus and then performing high-field transport measurements to extract the ionization coefficients for both electrons and holes. Avalanche gain in black phosphorus will also be characterized by illuminating the devices with near-band-edge light and using spatially-mapped photocurrent characterization. This work is intellectually significant in that it is expected to provide extensive fundamental insight into high-electric-field transport in black phosphorus. In particular, it will allow for an understanding of impact ionization, a fundamental process that is critical for the operation of nearly any practical device made from this material, including photodetectors, but also logic, memory and sensing transistors. Furthermore, this project will help to determine the means by which excess noise created from the combined avalanching of electrons and holes can be suppressed in black phosphorus in an analogous way to literature reports on germanium. This learning could ultimately lead to ground-breaking, low-cost, multi-spectral communication and imaging systems with improved speed and sensitivity compared to current solutions.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to evaluate and understand impact ionization in black phosphorus (BP), and to analyze the avalanche gain mechanism in BP avalanche photodiodes (APDs).

Avalanche photodiodes (APDs) are important devices for optical imaging and communications since they can provide ultra-high sensitivity (important for low-light environments) as well as high-speed operation. While APDs have been realized in a many materials, there remain few choices for APDs that can operate at long wavelengths (e.g. in mid-infrared wavelength range). BP is an extremely promising material for use in APDs due to its thickness tunable energy band gap and its high carrier mobility for both electrons and holes. Furthermore, BP can be exfoliated from bulk wafers and transferred onto arbitrary substrates, making it much easier to integrate onto silicon wafers than conventional narrow-gap III-V materials. However, little is known about the mechanisms for avalanche multiplication in BP and, therefore, the purpose of this project is to perform fundamental studies of the impact ionization and avalanche multiplication mechanisms in BP. The intellectual-merit-based achievements of the two-year project are detailed below:

In the first year of the project, the primary finding was that BP APDs were demonstrated and characterized for the first time.  Devices illuminated with green light (532 nm wavelength) displayed avalanche gain values > 200 at ~ 50 V applied bias. These gain values were considerably improved compared to APDs fabricated using other layered semiconductors. The results were significant in that they demonstrated that high avalanche gains could be achieved in BP and laid the foundation for further work in year 2 of the project.

In the second year of the project, additional details of the avalanche mechanism in BP were studied. In particular, it was found that impact ionization and carrier multiplication is much stronger for BP devices orientated in the "armchair" vs. the "zigzag" crystal direction.  In addition, it was found that much higher carrier multiplication was observed using short-wavelength (visible) illumination compared to longer wavelengths (infrared). This behavior was explained due to excess impact ionization produced by photogenerated carriers occupying higher energy states in the conduction band of BP. Full-band Monte Carlo modeling was used to confirm this explanation and provide quantitative estimates of the relative energy loss of carriers to phonons and impact ionization mechanisms.  Finally, vertical heterostructures consisting of BP with hexagonal boron nitride and graphene were fabricated and evaluated for use in ultra-high-speed photodetectors and optical modulators. Most interestingly, an electro-absorption-based optical modulator was demonstrated operating in the mid-infrared region and simulations were performed showing that optimized devices can be fabricated with performance exceeding that of current mid-infrared modulators.

The broader impact of this work is that it has provided new insights into the mechanisms of avalanche gain in BP which could improve the design of APDs using BP and other layered materials in the future. This work could also have important impacts for other types of devices, such as high-performance MOSFETs, where excessive impact ionization can lead to degradation of the device performance.  Finally, this work has also contributed to the professional development of graduate students and post-doctoral researchers, and has produced results that have been incorporated into a graduate education curriculum.
